page.title: 15MARKET RASEN-FEAST WEEK
page.content: The traditional 'Feast-Week' was held in May and October. There were opportunities for trading in livestock as well as other business and entertainments. The Market Place was thronged with cattle and sheep, and horses lined the length of Queen Street. Gradually the week starting on the Monday, became a time for enjoyment, so that by Saturday and Sunday trains brought people for round about. By 1858 it was reported that there were more visitors than before with the greasy pole being popular.After the Great War, the custom faded out. In the late 1960's, efforts were made by local business men to revive the October Feast-Week. This time the emphasis was on a trade fair with carnival processions, concerts and dances.
